## Brownian Motion

Brownian motion is the continuous-time limit of a discrete-time random walk.

+---------------------+---------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
|                     | Random Walk                                 | Brownian Motion                                                                    |
+=====================+=============================================+====================================================================================+
| Innovation          | $\epsilon_i\sim\text{WN}(0,1)$              | ![](fig/epsilon.png){width=200px}                                                  |
+---------------------+---------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Stochastic process  | $y_t = \epsilon_1 + \cdots + \epsilon_t$    | $X(r)_{r\in[0,1]} = \lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{i=1}^{nr}\epsilon_i$                    |
+---------------------+---------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Expectation         | $\mathbb E[y_t]=0$                          | $\mathbb E[X(r)] = 0$                                                              |
+---------------------+---------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Variance            | $\text{Var}[y_t]=t\text{Var}[\epsilon_i]=t$ | $\text{Var}[X(r)]=nr\text{Var}[\epsilon_i]=r$                                      |
+---------------------+---------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Quadratic variation | $\mathbb E\sum_{i=1}^{t}(y_i-y_{i-1})^2$    | $\mathbb E\int_{0}^{t} [\underbrace{X(r+dr)-X(r)}_{N(0,dr)}]^2 = \int_{0}^{t}dr=t$ |
|                     | $=\sum_{i=1}^{t}\mathbb{E}(\epsilon_i^2)=t$ |                                                                                    |
+---------------------+---------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

: Random Walk and Brownian Motion

Note that by Central Limit Theorem,

$$
\frac{1}{\sqrt{nr}} X(r) = \sqrt{nr}\frac{1}{nr}\sum_{i=1}^{nr}\epsilon_i\to N\left(0,\frac{1}{n}\right)
$$

Therefore, 

$$
X(r) \sim \sqrt{nr} N\left(0,\frac{1}{n}\right) \sim N(0,r)
$$

It follows that, for any $r<s$, 

$$
X(s) - X(r) \sim N(0, s-r)
$$

If $s$ and $r$ become arbitrarily close,

$$
dX \sim N(0, dr)
$$

$X(r)$ is called **Brownian motion** or **Wiener Process**.
